title: World's clearest lake ironically hidden away by dense mist most of the year
text:

The lake said to have the world's most crystal-clear waters is sure to be a sight to behold, but in an ironic twist most visitors won't be able to see them.

That's because more often than not, Japan's 'Lake of the Gods' is shrouded in a dense fog that hides the lake waters from view.

Lake Mashu, located in Akan National Park on the island of Hokkaido, is famed for the mysterious mist which often settles over the waters.

Unsurprisingly, there's plenty of myth surrounding the breathtaking spot.

In fact, you might be grateful if you show up on a misty day and can't see the water; legend has it that if you see into the surface waters clearly, it could bring bad luck to aspects of your family life or career.

Whether you visit on a clear or misty day is, quite fittingly, down to luck - it just depends on the weather that particular day.

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Still, that hasn't deterred intrepid explorers from heading to explore the spectacular landscape, with lush green scenery surrounding the pristine blue waters.

If you do want to visit, you can observe the lake from afar although authorities have prohibited visitors from getting close to the lake.

This has nothing to do with the risk of bad luck, but rather because the lake is actually situated within a crater of a potentially active volcano. Pair that with the dense fog and it doesn't exactly make for safe conditions.

(Image: Getty Images)

Still, there are two observation decks around the rim of the caldera lake, from which you can enjoy some pretty incredible panoramic views of the lake and its surroundings.

Even on misty days, the fog tends to be quite low so while it obscures views of the water, you can still take in the scenery.

There is also a hiking trail which measures about seven kilometres and takes you through the forest and grasslands if you do want to make the most of the great outdoors.

Because of its remote nature, the lake is easiest to reach by car, although there are some (infrequent) bus services from early February to mid March, and from April to November.

You can find out more on the official website .
description: It's said to have the world's most crystal-clear waters but visitors may not actually want to see them
